newsitem.title: PANAMA: Traffic controllers' strike shuts Panama airports.
newsitem.headline: Traffic controllers' strike shuts Panama airports.

text.p: Panama's airports were paralysed Tuesday by an air traffic controllers' strike over pay and pensions, a Civil Air Service spokeswoman said.
"Everything is closed. There is no air traffic because of the strike," she said.
Tocumen International Airport in Panama City, the nation's largest, was closed until further notice, she said. It normally handles about 200 flights a day.
The capital's Paitilla Airport, which handles about 250 flights of smaller commuter planes a day, was also closed, as were half a dozen other small airports across the country.
The 94 controllers walked out after talks with the government on a pay hike to $2,000 a month from an average of $600 broke down at the weekend.
They also want a package allowing them to retire earlier than the national average of 62 years for men and 57 years for women.
The spokeswoman said the strikers hoped to meet government officials again. The government said earlier it would fire the controllers if they went on strike.
